JOHN PATTISON WILLIAMS
October 23, 1953
My dear Mr. Fraziers
Thank you for your letter of October 21st and I am pleased to
give you a statement regarding George A. Bernstein, because I
feel he is a fine gentleman in every ivay, and I asstime that this
statement speaks for his character.
Regarding his qualifications, he has been unusually fortunate
because he has been in an over-all management position i?ith a
large company during the two years that I have known him. He
was specifically, during part of that period, responsible for
a single Radio Station operation as well. It is my feeling
that this qualifies him :*n a broader way than most people.
In connection with his ability, he not only gets along well
with people, but I have seen him go into a very trying situation
aqd increase volume and cut expenses - X know of no two actions
that are more necessary and vital In the operation of Stations.
If you have any further specific questions you would like to
3sk me, please feel free to do so."
It is my firm feeling that whoever has George working with them
will be extremely fortunate.
Very sincerely.
John Pattison Williams
Executive Vice President
Howard S. Frazier, Esq.
72& Bond Building
Washington 5, D. C.
